meta.name: holberton_addons
meta.description: Side-track modules inspired by Holberton/ALX advanced low-level and systems topics that are NOT covered (or lightly covered) in the main plan.json. This file is a separate curriculum: do NOT modify plan.json. Use this as an independent path for 'missing' advanced system-level skills and projects.
meta.note: This file is a companion side-track. It should be hosted/displayed separately from the main roadmap (plan.json). Each module has recommended placement relative to main plan phases (by phaseId).

modules.title: Advanced C: Memory, Pointers & UB
modules.summary: Deep dive into memory model, pointer arithmetic, undefined behaviour, aliasing, stack vs heap, alignment, and safe/unsafe patterns in C.
objectives: Master pointer arithmetic and complex data structures in C
Understand stack/heap layout, memory alignment and padding
Detect and avoid undefined behavior
Practice with memory-manipulating algorithms

modules.title: System Programming: Processes, Threads & Syscalls
modules.summary: Low-level system programming on Unix: creating processes, inter-process communication, threads, synchronization primitives, and common syscalls.
objectives: Create/manage processes with fork/exec/wait
Use pipes, sockets and shared memory
Write multi-threaded programs and use mutexes/condition variables
Understand race conditions and deadlocks and how to debug them

modules.title: Debugging & Diagnostic Tools (gdb, valgrind, strace, ltrace)
modules.summary: Practical mastery of debugging and diagnostic tools used in system-level development and large C projects.
objectives: Use gdb to step through programs, inspect memory and backtraces
Use valgrind to find leaks and undefined memory access
Use strace/ltrace to diagnose system call and library call behaviour
Integrate tooling into daily workflow and CI checks

modules.title: Low-level Networking & Sockets
modules.summary: Practical socket programming in C: TCP/UDP, blocking vs non-blocking I/O, select/poll/epoll, and basic network debugging.
objectives: Write TCP and UDP clients and servers in C
Understand and use select/poll/epoll for scalable servers
Diagnose networking issues with tcpdump/wireshark/netstat

modules.title: Operating Systems Internals (practical)
modules.summary: Hands-on OS concepts: processes scheduling, memory management, virtual memory, page tables, context switch, and a mini OS lab.
objectives: Understand virtual memory and page tables
Implement small kernel modules or simple OS experiments (user-mode emulation)
Study scheduling and resource management concepts with practical labs

modules.title: Compiler & Toolchain Practical (Front-End + Build)
modules.summary: Practical modules on lexing, parsing, ASTs and simple codegen; reading and extending small compilers; makefiles and build systems.
objectives: Implement lexer and parser for a tiny language
Build a simple AST and generate basic target code or bytecode
Master Makefiles, CMake basics and reproducible builds

modules.title: Concurrency & Parallelism (advanced)
modules.summary: Advanced concurrency patterns, memory models, lock-free programming basics, atomics, and performance considerations.
objectives: Understand C11 memory model/atomics
Implement producer-consumer, lock-free queues at exercise level
Profile multithreaded performance and avoid false sharing

modules.title: Profiling & Performance Optimization
modules.summary: Using profilers, cache-awareness, CPU performance counters, optimizing hot paths and algorithmic bottlenecks.
objectives: Use perf, gprof and other profilers to find hotspots
Understand cache locality and data structure layout
Apply basic SIMD/vectorization ideas at high level

modules.title: Security Basics & Reverse Engineering Intro
modules.summary: Foundational security topics: buffer overflows, DEP/ASLR, basic exploitation thinking and reversing small C programs.
objectives: Understand classic vulnerabilities and mitigation techniques
Practice safe C coding patterns to avoid security bugs
Use basic reversing tools (strings, objdump, radare/cutter)

resources.name: Smash The Stack/Intro to exploitation resources

modules.title: DevOps & Containers Practical
modules.summary: Hands-on with Docker, containers, basic orchestration, CI pipelines, infra as code basics and deploying simple system apps.
objectives: Containerize C and web apps using Docker
Create simple CI pipeline (GitHub Actions) for building and testing C projects
Understand basic infra as code (Terraform overview) and logging/monitoring basics

modules.title: Low-level Capstone Projects (Shell, Mini Debugger, Networked Server)
modules.summary: Project-based capstone: implement a simple shell, small debugger, and a networked multi-client server in C combining previous modules.
objectives: Ship production-quality small system projects
Apply debugging, profiling and testing practices
Create documentation and CI for projects

placement_guidance.explanation: Each module includes recommended_start_after_phase which maps to plan.json phaseId. Example: 3 means 'after Intro Programming + C Deep'. Use this file as a side-track visible in a separate 'Tracks' UI. The main roadmap (plan.json) must not be altered.
